Authors:
Cuong Quoc Tang, Ulrike Obertegger, Diego Fontaneto,
Timothy G. Barraclough
Title:
Reproductive Isolation rather than Discrete Environmental
Niches explains why Discrete Species Exist: a Comparison of Patterns of
Genetic Clustering between Sexual and Asexual Rotifers
Keywords:
ecological speciation, genetic cluster, species
delimitation, GMYC, population genetics, asexual, biodiversity,
speciation rate
Abstract:
Why species form discrete clusters instead of a continuum
of genotypic and phenotypic forms is an important yet rarely studied
question in speciation biology. Does species discreteness come from
adaptation to fill discrete niches or from interspecific gaps generated
by reproductive isolation? The importance of reproductive isolation can
be studied by comparing sexual and asexual taxa, but quantitative
comparisons are few. Here we compare the pattern of genetic discreteness
in ancient asexual bdelloid clades with sexual monogonont rotifers.
Evolutionarily significant units of diversity (species) were delimited
using the GMYC method, and their distinctness compared using measures of
intra- and interspecific variation. Although we find evidence for
significant clustering in both clades, monogonont species clusters are
more discrete than bdelloid species. The two clades display similar
average levels of within-cluster variation, but the divergence between
closest related clusters is greater in monogononts than in bdelloids.
Furthermore, the delimited clusters in bdelloids tend to contain far
fewer sequences per cluster than in monogononts and comprise
significantly more singletons. The findings most closely match
predictions if the environment is continuous, promoting genetic
divergence without discrete gaps in asexuals, and recombination mainly
explains the coherence of species clusters found in monogononts and
typical of sexual eukaryote groups.
